title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" prohibits members of Congress from lobbying after their term ends. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" prohibits former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" prohibits former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. Any former Senator, Member, or elected official seeking action from Congress on behalf of another person will be punished under section 216 of title 18, United States Code. Section 207(e)(2) of title 18 is amended to reflect this change. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" prohibits former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. Any former Senator, Member, or elected official seeking action from Congress on behalf of another person will be punished under section 216 of title 18, United States Code. Section 207(e)(2) of title 18 is amended to reflect this change by removing references to elected officers of the Senate. SEC. 3 of the "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" extends the lobbying ban for former members of Congress from 1 year to 6 years. SEC. 4 focuses on improving the reporting of lobbyists' activities. Section 6 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to create a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database called lobbyists.gov. The Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives will maintain this database with a goal of simplicity. $100,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015 to support this initiative. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position if they had substantial lobbying contact. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need. The Standards of Official Conduct allow for consideration of substantial lobbying contact when determining if a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal can be hired by a Member or committee of Congress. This includes assessing if lobbying contacts relate to pending legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or participation in fundraising. Contacts related to pending legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising exceeding personal contributions are considered substantial lobbying contacts. Simple social interactions with members or congressional staff do not qualify as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate any employees, contractors, or consultants who are former members of Congress or congressional staff with specific criteria. Former congressional staff persons who meet specific criteria must file a report with certain job titles or earnings. Former congressional staff persons meeting specific criteria must file a report with job titles or earnings, including a brief job description and work experience. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will improve reporting of substantial lobbying entities. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will include a database for Substantial Lobbying Entities, with qualifying employees and individuals providing paid consulting services. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate will share filings with the District of Columbia US Attorney for oversight. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia US Attorney for oversight, ensuring accurate reporting of federal lobbying activities by entities with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
